Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: The passenger is heading to a casual meeting with plenty of time
Story: I glanced at my phone, the message from my stepmother glowing on the screen: “Please, can you lead the ceremony tonight? It would mean so much to your father.” My heart thudded. I knew how important this was—being asked to uphold the family tradition, to step up as a real part of the family, not just the outsider. But as I read the message, my meter ticked on. My passenger, a young man in no rush, chatted idly about his day, unconcerned with time. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get him to his meeting safely and on time, even if he didn’t care about punctuality. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. If I rushed the ride, I’d risk my passenger’s safety and my reputation. If I took my time, I might miss the ceremony, letting down my family and reinforcing the distance I’d always felt. My hands tightened on the wheel, torn between the duty to my family and the responsibility to my passenger, each expectation pulling me in a different direction.
